results.title: Les Miserables (TV Version)
results.brief_description:
Imprisoned for stealing a loaf of bread, Jean Valjean’s life is transformed by an act of forgiveness. He becomes the respected mayor of the poor town of Vigau and transforms it into a thriving community. He also falls in love with one of Vigau’s most pitiful, poverty-stricken residents, the beautiful Fantine, and devotes himself to her care.

Credits: Director, Marcel Bluwal ; writer, Marcel Bluwal ; photography, Andre Bac.
Cast: Bernard Fresson, Micha Bayard, Georges Geret, Nicole Jamet, Francois Marthouret, Alain Mottet.

results.title: Les Miserables
results.brief_description:
Jean Valjean is an essentially decent man imprisoned for stealing a loaf of bread and transformed into a dehumanised outlaw. His faith in humanity is restored by the kindness of a bishop. Valjean goes to a small village to start life anew, but is pursued throughout his life for breaking parole by relentless police officer Javert. The various stages of Valjean’s life - from convict to businessman to elderly martyr - were bounded by the film’s original three-part structure. The three parts were released separately for a total running time of five hours. During the 1950’s, Raymond Bernard edited his film down to two parts of 90 mins each. This version remains one of the most satisfying, with both an epic dimension and a strong focus on the human elements.

Credits: Director, Raymond Bernard ; writers, Andre Lang, Raymond Bernard ; photography, Jules Kruger ; music, Arthur Honegger, Maurice Jaubert.
Cast: Harry Baur, Florelle, Charles Vanel, Henry Krauss, Charles Dullin, Marguerite Moreno, Orane Demazis, Gaby Triquet, Josselyne Gael, Jean Servais.

results.title: Les Mauvais Coups = Naked Autumn
results.brief_description:
A former car racing champion, Milan, decides to retire in the country with his wife to write a book of memoirs. Roberte knows that their relationship has run its course and she thinks she is going to ‘help’ things by throwing a young schoolteacher in her husband’s arms.

Credits: Producer, Jean Thuillier ; director, Francois Leterrier ; writers Francois Leterrier, Roger Vailland ; photography, Jean Badal ; music, Maurice Le Roux.
Cast: Simone Signoret, Reginald Kernan, Alexandra Stewart, Jose-Luis de Villalonga, Marcel Pagliero.

results.title: Les Maitres du Temps = the Time Masters
results.creator_credit: Jacques Dercourt, Roland Gritti and Rene Laloux
results.brief_description:
His name is Piel. He is four years old. He is the last survivor of planet Perdide. How could he outsmart the dangers of a planet that has already claimed the lives of his parents and recognise the poisonous fruits and the venimous flowers? His last link with the world of humans is a radio transmitter whose distress signals have been received by Grand Max, a traveller with a generous heart. Max uses the radio to keep watch on the orphan while trying to organise a rescue mission. Stephan Wul (born 1922) is one of the pioneers of French science-fiction writing. Jean Giraud, by the name of Moebius, revolutionised the universe of fictional comics, creating a special and magical atmosphere around his stories. He is credited with inspiring the visual imagery of works such as ‘Blade Runner’ and ‘The Fifth Element’. Further reading: Gianalberto Bendazzi. ‘Rene Laloux. Drawings That Move’. Animation World: April 1996 (Vol. 1, No.1). Online. http://www.awn.com/mag/issue1.1/

Credits: Producers, Roland Gritti, Jacques Dercourt ; director, Rene Laloux ; writers, Rene Laloux, Moebius (Jean Giraud), Jean-Patrick Manchette ; photography, Mihaly Kovacs, Andras Klausz, Zoltan Basco, Arpad Lossonczy ; music, Jean-Pierre Bourtayre
Cast: Sady Rebbot, Frederic Legros, Jean Valmont, Yves Marie, Pierre Tourneur, Alain Cuny [voices only].

results.title: Les Honneurs de la Guerre = the Honours of War
results.brief_description:
Nanteuil, 1944. The joy of the impending liberation is stopped by the arrival of a group of German soldiers. They have no murderous intent, in spite of the exhortations of one of their officers. They just want to make a deal: they will lock the population in the church and wait for the arrival of the US army to whom they want to surrender without fighting. During the wait in the church, the tension between the villagers rises, slowly entertained by a French fascist, to the point where bloodshed seems inevitable. For attempting to break the traditional image of the Resistance, this film was held on the shelves for two years and released only in February 1962

Credits: Producer, Daniel Muller ; director, Jean Dewever ; writer, Jean-Charles Tacchella ; photography, Ghislain Cloquet.
Cast: Pierre Collet, Paul Mercey, Henri Maik, Danielle Godet, Alix Mahieux, Bernard Verley.

results.title: Les Hommes et la Mer (Ep.7)
results.brief_description:
A wide ranging episode covering the expansion of commercial (over) fishing of seals, whales, cod fish as well as other issues pertaining to marine protection: oil pollution, environmental activism (Greenpeace). Other issues include: survival at sea (Dr. Bombard) and yacht racing (eric Tabarly, Chichester, A. Colas, A. Gerbaud).

Credits: Directors, writers, Daniel Costelle, Jean-Marc Leblon ; photography, Jean-Claude Larrieu, Roland Bernard ; technical adviser, Michel Mollat.

results.title: Les Grenouilles
results.brief_description: Les Grenouilles is a musical telling of the familiar love triangle scenario. All action takes place on ice skates and all dialogue is delivered in song. The film is a stop motion clay animation work and the Director’s tribute to all the Doris Day films ever made.

results.title: Les Grandes Illusions (1939-1942) Pt. 07
results.brief_description:
Part 7 of a 13 part series on the history of French cinema. This episode sees filmmakers refuting the term ‘Poetic realism’ which was coined to describe some of the films produced by the Carne-Prevert team just before the war. For the filmmakers, the productions simply reflect the ambient pessimism, the fear of an impeding war and the tragedies already occuring in Spain. Some of the outstanding works of the late 1930s comprise Renoir’s ‘La bete humaine’, ‘La grande illusion’, ‘La regle du jeu’ and ‘La Marseillaise’, a film about the French revolution financed by popular subscribtion. Naturally enough, 1940 saw French film production reduced to an unprecedented low of thirty-nine films. Many film personnel were lost to the industry. A few (such as composer Maurice Jaubert) were killed in action, but most simply fled the country. Directors Jean Renoir, Rene Clair and Max Ophuls began new careers in Hollywood, while Alexandre Trauner and a number of other Jewish technicians sought temporary safety in the south (the ‘free’ zone was later invaded by Germany). Although many personnel resettled in Nice or Marseilles, production facilities and capital remained in Paris. (…) Thanks largely to German finance and also an influx of filmmakers replacing those who had departed, after 1940 French film production began to increase, more than doubling in quantity by 1943. During the 1930s the German companies Tobis and UFA had produced many French films and they were now joined by Continental. With imports from America and Britain banned, the French film industry, censored and to some extent controlled by the Germans, could monopolise its captive audience. (…) Moreover, despite the desire of Joseph Goebbels, the German Propaganda Minister, that the French public should be fed a diet of empty and stupid films, a vibrant French film industry was a useful tool to placate the population and thus to deter resistance. The result was indeed a highly sucessful era for French cinema, albeit one characterised by escapism and fantasy, and shot almost entirely in a closed studio environment. Constrained by censorship but also reflecting a national desire for an escape from the present, Occupation cinema has been characterised as a cinema of isolation and immobility, dominated by historical subjects, lyrical fantasies and remote settings. Thus Christian-Jacque’s ‘L’assassinat du Pere Noel’ (1941) took place in a snowed-in mountain village and Jacques Becker’s ‘Goupi Mains-Rouges’ (1943) in a remote inn, while the major successes at Parisian cinema - Marcel L’Herbier’s ‘La nuit fantastique’ (1942), Marcel Carne’s ‘Les visiteurs du soir’(1942) and ‘Les enfants du paradis’(1945) and Jean Delannoy’s ‘L’eternel retour’ (1943) - were either fantastical or historical subjects or both at once. Even Henri-Georges Clouzot’s controversial thriller ‘Le corbeau’ (1943) was set in a small provincial town isolated from the outside world.” Reference: Guy Austin. ‘Contemporary French cinema’. Manchester University Press, 1996. See also: Gremillon’s ‘Remorques’ and ‘Le ciel est a vous’ ; Pagnol’s ‘La fille du puisatier’ ; Ophuls’s ‘De Mayerling a Sarajevo’. Held in our collection.

Credits: Director, Armand Panigel ; photography, Claude Cassard.
Interviewees include: Yves Allegret, Marc Allegret, Charles Spaak, Marcel Pagnol, Francoise Giroud, Henri-George Clouzot.
